trans-unit.source: Many modern web-based solutions make the use of web services, hosted by web servers, to provide functionality for remote client applications.
trans-unit.target: Many modern web-based solutions make the use of web services, hosted by web servers, to provide functionality for remote client applications.

trans-unit.source: The operations that a web service exposes constitute a web API.
trans-unit.target: The operations that a web service exposes constitute a web API.

trans-unit.source: A well-designed web API should aim to support:
trans-unit.target: A well-designed web API should aim to support:

trans-unit.source: Platform independence.
trans-unit.target: Platform independence.

trans-unit.source: Client applications should be able to utilize the API that the web service provides without requiring how the data or operations that API exposes are physically implemented.
trans-unit.target: Client applications should be able to utilize the API that the web service provides without requiring how the data or operations that API exposes are physically implemented.

trans-unit.source: This requires that the API abides by common standards that enable a client application and web service to agree on which data formats to use, and the structure of the data that is exchanged between client applications and the web service.
trans-unit.target: This requires that the API abides by common standards that enable a client application and web service to agree on which data formats to use, and the structure of the data that is exchanged between client applications and the web service.

trans-unit.source: Service evolution.
trans-unit.target: Service evolution.

trans-unit.source: The web service should be able to evolve and add (or remove) functionality independently from client applications.
trans-unit.target: The web service should be able to evolve and add (or remove) functionality independently from client applications.

trans-unit.source: Existing client applications should be able to continue to operate unmodified as the features provided by the web service change.
trans-unit.target: Existing client applications should be able to continue to operate unmodified as the features provided by the web service change.

trans-unit.source: All functionality should also be discoverable, so that client applications can fully utilize it.
trans-unit.target: All functionality should also be discoverable, so that client applications can fully utilize it.

trans-unit.source: The purpose of this guidance is to describe the issues that you should consider when designing a web API.
trans-unit.target: The purpose of this guidance is to describe the issues that you should consider when designing a web API.

trans-unit.source: In his dissertation in 2000, Roy Fielding proposed an alternative architectural approach to structuring the operations exposed by web services; REST.
trans-unit.target: In his dissertation in 2000, Roy Fielding proposed an alternative architectural approach to structuring the operations exposed by web services; REST.

trans-unit.source: REST is an architectural style for building distributed systems based on hypermedia.
trans-unit.target: REST is an architectural style for building distributed systems based on hypermedia.

trans-unit.source: A primary advantage of the REST model is that it is based on open standards and does not bind the implementation of the model or the client applications that access it to any specific implementation.
trans-unit.target: A primary advantage of the REST model is that it is based on open standards and does not bind the implementation of the model or the client applications that access it to any specific implementation.

trans-unit.source: For example, a REST web service could be implemented by using the Microsoft ASP.NET Web API, and client applications could be developed by using any language and toolset that can generate HTTP requests and parse HTTP responses.
trans-unit.target: For example, a REST web service could be implemented by using the Microsoft ASP.NET Web API, and client applications could be developed by using any language and toolset that can generate HTTP requests and parse HTTP responses.

trans-unit.source: : REST is actually independent of any underlying protocol and is not necessarily tied to HTTP.
trans-unit.target: : REST is actually independent of any underlying protocol and is not necessarily tied to HTTP.

trans-unit.source: However, most common implementations of systems that are based on REST utilize HTTP as the application protocol for sending and receiving requests.
trans-unit.target: However, most common implementations of systems that are based on REST utilize HTTP as the application protocol for sending and receiving requests.

trans-unit.source: This document focusses on mapping REST principles to systems designed to operate using HTTP.
trans-unit.target: This document focusses on mapping REST principles to systems designed to operate using HTTP.

trans-unit.source: The REST model uses a navigational scheme to represent objects and services over a network (referred to as resources).
trans-unit.target: The REST model uses a navigational scheme to represent objects and services over a network (referred to as resources).

trans-unit.source: Many systems that implement REST typically use the HTTP protocol to transmit requests to access these resources.
trans-unit.target: Many systems that implement REST typically use the HTTP protocol to transmit requests to access these resources.

trans-unit.source: In these systems, a client application submits a request in the form of a URI that identifies a resource, and an HTTP method (the most common being GET, POST, PUT, or DELETE) that indicates the operation to be performed on that resource.
trans-unit.target: In these systems, a client application submits a request in the form of a URI that identifies a resource, and an HTTP method (the most common being GET, POST, PUT, or DELETE) that indicates the operation to be performed on that resource.

trans-unit.source: The body of the HTTP request contains the data required to perform the operation.
trans-unit.target: The body of the HTTP request contains the data required to perform the operation.

trans-unit.source: The important point to understand is that REST defines a stateless request model.
trans-unit.target: The important point to understand is that REST defines a stateless request model.

trans-unit.source: HTTP requests should be independent and may occur in any order, so attempting to retain transient state information between requests is not feasible.
trans-unit.target: HTTP requests should be independent and may occur in any order, so attempting to retain transient state information between requests is not feasible.

trans-unit.source: The only place where information is stored is in the resources themselves, and each request should be an atomic operation.
trans-unit.target: The only place where information is stored is in the resources themselves, and each request should be an atomic operation.

trans-unit.source: Effectively, a REST model implements a finite state machine where a request transitions a resource from one well-defined non-transient state to another.
trans-unit.target: Effectively, a REST model implements a finite state machine where a request transitions a resource from one well-defined non-transient state to another.

trans-unit.source: The stateless nature of individual requests in the REST model enables a system constructed by following these principles to be highly scalable.
trans-unit.target: The stateless nature of individual requests in the REST model enables a system constructed by following these principles to be highly scalable.

trans-unit.source: There is no need to retain any affinity between a client application making a series of requests and the specific web servers handling those requests.
trans-unit.target: There is no need to retain any affinity between a client application making a series of requests and the specific web servers handling those requests.

trans-unit.source: Another crucial point in implementing an effective REST model is to understand the relationships between the various resources to which the model provides access.
trans-unit.target: Another crucial point in implementing an effective REST model is to understand the relationships between the various resources to which the model provides access.

trans-unit.source: These resources are typically organized as collections and relationships.
trans-unit.target: These resources are typically organized as collections and relationships.

trans-unit.source: For example, suppose that a quick analysis of an ecommerce system shows that there are two collections in which client applications are likely to be interested: orders and customers.
trans-unit.target: For example, suppose that a quick analysis of an ecommerce system shows that there are two collections in which client applications are likely to be interested: orders and customers.

trans-unit.target: Each order and customer should have its own unique key for identification purposes.

trans-unit.target: The URI to access the collection of orders could be something as simple as /orders, and similarly the URI for retrieving all customers could be /customers.

trans-unit.source: However, there is no reason why resources should not contain any other type of data supported by HTTP, such as binary or encrypted information; the content-type in the HTTP response should specify the type.
trans-unit.target: However, there is no reason why resources should not contain any other type of data supported by HTTP, such as binary or encrypted information; the content-type in the HTTP response should specify the type.

trans-unit.source: Also, a REST model may be able to return the same data in different formats, such as XML or JSON.
trans-unit.target: Also, a REST model may be able to return the same data in different formats, such as XML or JSON.

trans-unit.source: In this case, the web service should be able to perform content negotiation with the client making the request.
trans-unit.target: In this case, the web service should be able to perform content negotiation with the client making the request.

trans-unit.source: The request can include an Accept header which specifies the preferred format that the client would like to receive and the web service should attempt to honor this format if at all possible.
trans-unit.target: The request can include an Accept header which specifies the preferred format that the client would like to receive and the web service should attempt to honor this format if at all possible.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the response from a REST request makes use of the standard HTTP status codes.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the response from a REST request makes use of the standard HTTP status codes.

trans-unit.source: For example, a request that returns valid data should include the HTTP response code 200 (OK), while a request that fails to find or delete a specified resource should return a response that includes the HTTP status code 404 (Not Found).
trans-unit.target: For example, a request that returns valid data should include the HTTP response code 200 (OK), while a request that fails to find or delete a specified resource should return a response that includes the HTTP status code 404 (Not Found).

trans-unit.source: The keys to designing a successful web API are simplicity and consistency.
trans-unit.target: The keys to designing a successful web API are simplicity and consistency.

trans-unit.source: A Web API that exhibits these two factors makes it easier to build client applications that need to consume the API.
trans-unit.target: A Web API that exhibits these two factors makes it easier to build client applications that need to consume the API.

trans-unit.source: A RESTful web API is focused on exposing a set of connected resources, and providing the core operations that enable an application to manipulate these resources and easily navigate between them.
trans-unit.target: A RESTful web API is focused on exposing a set of connected resources, and providing the core operations that enable an application to manipulate these resources and easily navigate between them.

trans-unit.source: For this reason, the URIs that constitute a typical RESTful web API should be oriented towards the data that it exposes, and use the facilities provided by HTTP to operate on this data.
trans-unit.target: For this reason, the URIs that constitute a typical RESTful web API should be oriented towards the data that it exposes, and use the facilities provided by HTTP to operate on this data.

trans-unit.source: This approach requires a different mindset from that typically employed when designing a set of classes in an object-oriented API which tends to be more motivated by the behavior of objects and classes.
trans-unit.target: This approach requires a different mindset from that typically employed when designing a set of classes in an object-oriented API which tends to be more motivated by the behavior of objects and classes.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, a RESTful web API should be stateless and not depend on operations being invoked in a particular sequence.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, a RESTful web API should be stateless and not depend on operations being invoked in a particular sequence.

trans-unit.source: The following sections summarize the points you should consider when designing a RESTful web API.
trans-unit.target: The following sections summarize the points you should consider when designing a RESTful web API.

trans-unit.source: The URIs exposed by a REST web service should be based on nouns (the data to which the web API provides access) and not verbs (what an application can do with the data).
trans-unit.target: The URIs exposed by a REST web service should be based on nouns (the data to which the web API provides access) and not verbs (what an application can do with the data).

trans-unit.source: Focus on the business entities that the web API exposes.
trans-unit.target: Focus on the business entities that the web API exposes.

trans-unit.source: For example, in a web API designed to support the ecommerce system described earlier, the primary entities are customers and orders.
trans-unit.target: For example, in a web API designed to support the ecommerce system described earlier, the primary entities are customers and orders.

trans-unit.source: Processes such as the act of placing an order can be achieved by providing an HTTP POST operation that takes the order information and adds it to the list of orders for the customer.
trans-unit.target: Processes such as the act of placing an order can be achieved by providing an HTTP POST operation that takes the order information and adds it to the list of orders for the customer.

trans-unit.source: Internally, this POST operation can perform tasks such as checking stock levels, and billing the customer.
trans-unit.target: Internally, this POST operation can perform tasks such as checking stock levels, and billing the customer.

trans-unit.source: The HTTP response can indicate whether the order was placed successfully or not.
trans-unit.target: The HTTP response can indicate whether the order was placed successfully or not.

trans-unit.source: Also note that a resource does not have to be based on a single physical data item.
trans-unit.target: Also note that a resource does not have to be based on a single physical data item.

trans-unit.source: As an example, an order resource might be implemented internally by using information aggregated from many rows spread across several tables in a relational database but presented to the client as a single entity.
trans-unit.target: As an example, an order resource might be implemented internally by using information aggregated from many rows spread across several tables in a relational database but presented to the client as a single entity.

trans-unit.source: Avoid designing a REST interface that mirrors or depends on the internal structure of the data that it exposes.
trans-unit.target: Avoid designing a REST interface that mirrors or depends on the internal structure of the data that it exposes.

trans-unit.source: REST is about more than implementing simple CRUD (Create, Retrieve, Update, Delete) operations over separate tables in a relational database.
trans-unit.target: REST is about more than implementing simple CRUD (Create, Retrieve, Update, Delete) operations over separate tables in a relational database.

trans-unit.source: The purpose of REST is to map business entities and the operations that an application can perform on these entities to the physical implementation of these entities, but a client should not be exposed to these physical details.
trans-unit.target: The purpose of REST is to map business entities and the operations that an application can perform on these entities to the physical implementation of these entities, but a client should not be exposed to these physical details.

trans-unit.source: Individual business entities rarely exist in isolation (although some singleton objects may exist), but instead tend to be grouped together into collections.
trans-unit.target: Individual business entities rarely exist in isolation (although some singleton objects may exist), but instead tend to be grouped together into collections.

trans-unit.source: In REST terms, each entity and each collection are resources.
trans-unit.target: In REST terms, each entity and each collection are resources.

trans-unit.source: In a RESTful web API, each collection has its own URI within the web service, and performing an HTTP GET request over a URI for a collection retrieves a list of items in that collection.
trans-unit.target: In a RESTful web API, each collection has its own URI within the web service, and performing an HTTP GET request over a URI for a collection retrieves a list of items in that collection.

trans-unit.source: Each individual item also has its own URI, and an application can submit another HTTP GET request using that URI to retrieve the details of that item.
trans-unit.target: Each individual item also has its own URI, and an application can submit another HTTP GET request using that URI to retrieve the details of that item.

trans-unit.source: You should organize the URIs for collections and items in a hierarchical manner.
trans-unit.target: You should organize the URIs for collections and items in a hierarchical manner.

trans-unit.source: In the ecommerce system, the URI /customers denotes the customer’s collection, and /customers/5 retrieves the details for the single customer with the ID 5 from this collection.
trans-unit.target: In the ecommerce system, the URI /customers denotes the customer’s collection, and /customers/5 retrieves the details for the single customer with the ID 5 from this collection.

trans-unit.source: This approach helps to keep the web API intuitive.
trans-unit.target: This approach helps to keep the web API intuitive.

trans-unit.source: Adopt a consistent naming convention in URIs; in general it helps to use plural nouns for URIs that reference collections.
trans-unit.target: Adopt a consistent naming convention in URIs; in general it helps to use plural nouns for URIs that reference collections.

trans-unit.source: You also need to consider the relationships between different types of resources and how you might expose these associations.
trans-unit.target: You also need to consider the relationships between different types of resources and how you might expose these associations.

trans-unit.source: For example, customers may place zero or more orders.
trans-unit.target: For example, customers may place zero or more orders.

trans-unit.source: A natural way to represent this relationship would be through a URI such as /customers/5/orders to find all the orders for customer 5.
trans-unit.target: A natural way to represent this relationship would be through a URI such as /customers/5/orders to find all the orders for customer 5.

trans-unit.source: You might also consider representing the association from an order back to a specific customer through a URI such as /orders/99/customer to find the customer for order 99, but extending this model too far can become cumbersome to implement.
trans-unit.target: You might also consider representing the association from an order back to a specific customer through a URI such as /orders/99/customer to find the customer for order 99, but extending this model too far can become cumbersome to implement.

trans-unit.source: A better solution is to provide navigable links to associated resources, such as the customer, in the body of the HTTP response message returned when the order is queried.
trans-unit.target: A better solution is to provide navigable links to associated resources, such as the customer, in the body of the HTTP response message returned when the order is queried.

trans-unit.source: This mechanism is described in more detail in the section Using the HATEOAS Approach to Enable Navigation To Related Resources later in this guidance.
trans-unit.target: This mechanism is described in more detail in the section Using the HATEOAS Approach to Enable Navigation To Related Resources later in this guidance.

trans-unit.source: In more complex systems there may be many more types of entity, and it can be tempting to provide URIs that enable a client application to navigate through several levels of relationships, such as /customers/1/orders/99/products to obtain the list of products in order 99 placed by customer 1.
trans-unit.target: In more complex systems there may be many more types of entity, and it can be tempting to provide URIs that enable a client application to navigate through several levels of relationships, such as /customers/1/orders/99/products to obtain the list of products in order 99 placed by customer 1.

trans-unit.source: However, this level of complexity can be difficult to maintain and is inflexible if the relationships between resources change in the future.
trans-unit.target: However, this level of complexity can be difficult to maintain and is inflexible if the relationships between resources change in the future.

trans-unit.source: Rather, you should seek to keep URIs relatively simple.
trans-unit.target: Rather, you should seek to keep URIs relatively simple.

trans-unit.source: Bear in mind that once an application has a reference to a resource, it should be possible to use this reference to find items related to that resource.
trans-unit.target: Bear in mind that once an application has a reference to a resource, it should be possible to use this reference to find items related to that resource.

trans-unit.source: The preceding query can be replaced with the URI /customers/1/orders to find all the orders for customer 1, and then query the URI /orders/99/products to find the products in this order (assuming order 99 was placed by customer 1).
trans-unit.target: The preceding query can be replaced with the URI /customers/1/orders to find all the orders for customer 1, and then query the URI /orders/99/products to find the products in this order (assuming order 99 was placed by customer 1).

trans-unit.source: Avoid requiring resource URIs more complex than collection/item/collection.
trans-unit.target: Avoid requiring resource URIs more complex than collection/item/collection.

trans-unit.source: Another point to consider is that all web requests impose a load on the web server, and the greater the number of requests the bigger the load.
trans-unit.target: Another point to consider is that all web requests impose a load on the web server, and the greater the number of requests the bigger the load.

trans-unit.source: You should attempt to define your resources to avoid “chatty” web APIs that expose a large number of small resources.
trans-unit.target: You should attempt to define your resources to avoid “chatty” web APIs that expose a large number of small resources.

trans-unit.source: Such an API may require a client application to submit multiple requests to find all the data that it requires.
trans-unit.target: Such an API may require a client application to submit multiple requests to find all the data that it requires.

trans-unit.source: It may be beneficial to denormalize data and combine related information together into bigger resources that can be retrieved by issuing a single request.
trans-unit.target: It may be beneficial to denormalize data and combine related information together into bigger resources that can be retrieved by issuing a single request.

trans-unit.source: However, you need to balance this approach against the overhead of fetching data that might not be frequently required by the client.
trans-unit.target: However, you need to balance this approach against the overhead of fetching data that might not be frequently required by the client.

trans-unit.source: Retrieving large objects can increase the latency of a request and incur additional bandwidth costs for little advantage if the additional data is not often used.
trans-unit.target: Retrieving large objects can increase the latency of a request and incur additional bandwidth costs for little advantage if the additional data is not often used.

trans-unit.source: Avoid introducing dependencies between the web API to the structure, type, or location of the underlying data sources.
trans-unit.target: Avoid introducing dependencies between the web API to the structure, type, or location of the underlying data sources.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your data is located in a relational database, the web API does not need to expose each table as a collection of resources.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your data is located in a relational database, the web API does not need to expose each table as a collection of resources.

trans-unit.source: Think of the web API as an abstraction of the database, and if necessary introduce a mapping layer between the database and the web API.
trans-unit.target: Think of the web API as an abstraction of the database, and if necessary introduce a mapping layer between the database and the web API.

trans-unit.source: In this way, if the design or implementation of the database changes (for example, you move from a relational database containing a collection of normalized tables to a denormalized NoSQL storage system such as a document database) client applications are insulated from these changes.
trans-unit.target: In this way, if the design or implementation of the database changes (for example, you move from a relational database containing a collection of normalized tables to a denormalized NoSQL storage system such as a document database) client applications are insulated from these changes.

trans-unit.source: The source of the data that underpins a web API does not have to be a data store; it could be another service or line-of-business application or even a legacy application running on-premises within an organization.
trans-unit.target: The source of the data that underpins a web API does not have to be a data store; it could be another service or line-of-business application or even a legacy application running on-premises within an organization.

trans-unit.source: Finally, it might not be possible to map every operation implemented by a web API to a specific resource. You can handle such non-resource scenarios through HTTP GET requests that invoke a piece of functionality and return the results as an HTTP response message. A web API that implements simple calculator-style operations such as add and subtract could provide URIs that expose these operations as pseudo resources and utilize the query string to specify the parameters required. For example a GET request to the URI /add?operand1=99&operand2=1 could return a response message with the body containing the value 100, and GET request to the URI /subtract?operand1=50&operand2=20 could return a response message with the body containing the value 30. However, only use these forms of URIs sparingly.

trans-unit.source: The HTTP protocol defines a number of methods that assign semantic meaning to a request.

trans-unit.source: The common HTTP methods used by most RESTful web APIs are:
trans-unit.target: The common HTTP methods used by most RESTful web APIs are:

trans-unit.source: GET, to retrieve a copy of the resource at the specified URI.
trans-unit.target: GET, to retrieve a copy of the resource at the specified URI.

trans-unit.source: The body of the response message contains the details of the requested resource.
trans-unit.target: The body of the response message contains the details of the requested resource.

trans-unit.source: POST, to create a new resource at the specified URI.
trans-unit.target: POST, to create a new resource at the specified URI.

trans-unit.source: The body of the request message provides the details of the new resource.
trans-unit.target: The body of the request message provides the details of the new resource.

trans-unit.target: Note that POST can also be used to trigger operations that don't actually create resources.

trans-unit.source: PUT, to replace or update the resource at the specified URI.
trans-unit.target: PUT, to replace or update the resource at the specified URI.

trans-unit.source: The body of the request message specifies the resource to be modified and the values to be applied.
trans-unit.target: The body of the request message specifies the resource to be modified and the values to be applied.

trans-unit.source: DELETE, to remove the resource at the specified URI.
trans-unit.target: DELETE, to remove the resource at the specified URI.

trans-unit.source: Existing client applications might continue functioning correctly if they are capable of ignoring unrecognized fields, while new client applications can be designed to handle this new field.

trans-unit.source: However, if more radical changes to the schema of resources occur (such as removing or renaming fields) or the relationships between resources change then these may constitute breaking changes that prevent existing client applications from functioning correctly.

trans-unit.source: In these situations you should consider one of the following approaches.

trans-unit.source: Each time you modify the web API or change the schema of resources, you add a version number to the URI for each resource.
trans-unit.target: Each time you modify the web API or change the schema of resources, you add a version number to the URI for each resource.

trans-unit.source: The previously existing URIs should continue to operate as before, returning resources that conform to their original schema.

trans-unit.source: This versioning mechanism is very simple but depends on the server routing the request to the appropriate endpoint.

trans-unit.source: However, it can become unwieldy as the web API matures through several iterations and the server has to support a number of different versions.

trans-unit.source: Also, from a purist’s point of view, in all cases the client applications are fetching the same data (customer 3), so the URI should not really be different depending on the version.
trans-unit.target: Also, from a purist’s point of view, in all cases the client applications are fetching the same data (customer 3), so the URI should not really be different depending on the version.

trans-unit.source: This scheme also complicates implementation of HATEOAS as all links will need to include the version number in their URIs.
trans-unit.target: This scheme also complicates implementation of HATEOAS as all links will need to include the version number in their URIs.

trans-unit.source: Rather than providing multiple URIs, you can specify the version of the resource by using a parameter within the query string appended to the HTTP request, such as http://adventure-works.com/customers/3?version=2.
trans-unit.target: Rather than providing multiple URIs, you can specify the version of the resource by using a parameter within the query string appended to the HTTP request, such as http://adventure-works.com/customers/3?version=2.

trans-unit.source: The version parameter should default to a meaningful value such as 1 if it is omitted by older client applications.
trans-unit.target: The version parameter should default to a meaningful value such as 1 if it is omitted by older client applications.

trans-unit.source: This approach has the semantic advantage that the same resource is always retrieved from the same URI, but it depends on the code that handles the request to parse the query string and send back the appropriate HTTP response.
trans-unit.target: This approach has the semantic advantage that the same resource is always retrieved from the same URI, but it depends on the code that handles the request to parse the query string and send back the appropriate HTTP response.

trans-unit.source: This approach also suffers from the same complications for implementing HATEOAS as the URI versioning mechanism.
trans-unit.target: This approach also suffers from the same complications for implementing HATEOAS as the URI versioning mechanism.

trans-unit.source: Some older web browsers and web proxies will not cache responses for requests that include a query string in the URL.
trans-unit.target: Some older web browsers and web proxies will not cache responses for requests that include a query string in the URL.

trans-unit.source: This can have an adverse impact on performance for web applications that use a web API and that run from within such a web browser.
trans-unit.target: This can have an adverse impact on performance for web applications that use a web API and that run from within such a web browser.

trans-unit.source: Rather than appending the version number as a query string parameter, you could implement a custom header that indicates the version of the resource.
trans-unit.target: Rather than appending the version number as a query string parameter, you could implement a custom header that indicates the version of the resource.

trans-unit.source: When a client application sends an HTTP GET request to a web server it should stipulate the format of the content that it can handle by using an Accept header, as described earlier in this guidance.
trans-unit.target: When a client application sends an HTTP GET request to a web server it should stipulate the format of the content that it can handle by using an Accept header, as described earlier in this guidance.

trans-unit.source: Frequently the purpose of the Accept header is to allow the client application to specify whether the body of the response should be XML, JSON, or some other common format that the client can parse.
trans-unit.target: Frequently the purpose of the Accept header is to allow the client application to specify whether the body of the response should be XML, JSON, or some other common format that the client can parse.

trans-unit.source: However, it is possible to define custom media types that include information enabling the client application to indicate which version of a resource it is expecting.

trans-unit.source: When you select a versioning strategy, you should also consider the implications on performance, especially caching on the web server.

trans-unit.source: The URI versioning and Query String versioning schemes are cache-friendly inasmuch as the same URI/query string combination refers to the same data each time.

trans-unit.source: The Header versioning and Media Type versioning mechanisms typically require additional logic to examine the values in the custom header or the Accept header.

trans-unit.source: In a large-scale environment, many clients using different versions of a web API can result in a significant amount of duplicated data in a server-side cache.

trans-unit.source: This issue can become acute if a client application communicates with a web server through a proxy that implements caching, and that only forwards a request to the web server if it does not currently hold a copy of the requested data in its cache.
